examples.explanation: List all supported gcode

G0.description: Perform retract using firmware configured retraction setting.

G1.description: G1 is used to position the tool at a specific feed rate. The speed (feedrate) can be set with F*feedrate* and E *amount* amount of material can be extruded during the move. The firmware coordinates moves so that the feed rate for each axis and extruder is consistent and predictable. S can be used to check for endstops (S0: check, S1: ignore) but may not be implemented by your firmware.

examples.explanation: Move to 100,100 on the X and Y planes

parameters.description: Move n units along the X axis.
Move n units along the Y axis.
Move n units along the Z axis.
Set feedrate. Moves after this command will move at this rate (or slower).
S0 Ignore endstops, S1 Check for endstop. Disabling endstops may not be supported by some firmware.

G1.usage notes: G0 and G1 may be interpreted as the same command in some firmware.

examples.explanation: Move to 105,105 in a clockwise arc around 100, 100.

G2.format: G2 [X{POSITION} Y{POSITION} I{DISTANCE} J{DISTANCE} E{AMOUNT} F{FEEDRATE}]

parameters.description: Set feedrate. May be used alone to set a start and ending feed rate.

G2.usage notes: Move to the X,Y coordinates in an arc with a center of I,J.

G20.usage notes: Instruct the printer to interpret units in inches.

G21.usage notes: Instruct the printer to interpret units in millimeters.

G28.description: Home.  Specify an axis, several, or use G28 with no parameters to home all.

examples.explanation: Instruct the printer to seek the configured endstop for both X and Y.
Home all.

G28.usage notes: G28 will cause an axis to seek its configured endstop.  Smoothieware features a number of G28 sub commands implemented as G28.n.

examples.explanation: Initiate Z probing/Automatic Bed Leveling.

G29.usage notes: The Z probing process may be firmware dependent and configurable.  The routine should perform any required actions (such as deploying a probe, picking up a sled, etc) to prepare the tool to probe and configure Z.  Depending on configuration, this may also initiate any automatic bed leveling (ABL) features in the firmware.

examples.explanation: Move to 105,105 in a counter-clockwise arc around 100, 100.

G3.format: G3 [X{POSITION} Y{POSITION} I{DISTANCE} J{DISTANCE} E{AMOUNT} F{FEEDRATE}]

parameters.description: Set feedrate. May be used alone to set a start and ending feed rate.

G3.usage notes: Move to the X,Y coordinates in an arc with a center of I,J.

G30.description: Probe single point with the Z probe and save as Point P.

examples.explanation: Seek Z = 0 at X = 0, Y = 0 and save as point P.

G30.usage notes: Seek until Z probe is triggered at a specific point and report when triggered.  Extended options may be available in your firmware.

G4.description: Wait for a specific amount of time before continuing.

G90.description: Configure printer to use absolute movements.

examples.explanation: Instruct the tool to move to absolute coordinate 5,5.

G90.usage notes: Movement by the tool will be interpreted as an absolute coordinate.

G91.description: Configure printer to use relative movements.

examples.explanation: Instruct the tool to move to +5 units from the current position on the X axis.

G91.usage notes: Movement by the tool will be interpreted as relative to the current position of the tool.

examples.explanation: List all supported mcode.
Retract 1mm during retraction requests.
Retract 1mm during retraction requests at 12 mm/minute and also lift the tool (hop) by 1mm while retracting.

parameters.description: Retract {n} units.  {n} is expected to be a positive number.
Amount to raise the tool during firmware retract.

M207.usage notes: Using firmware retraction helps to make gcode more portable and easier to maintain across printers or filament types.  Smoothieware implements an additional Q parameter for specifying the Z lift feed rate.

examples.explanation: Save configuration.

M500.usage notes: User configurable settings are saved to storage.  The settings that are saved are firmware dependent.  For Marlin, this saves to the eeprom, while Redeem and Smoothie save to files.

examples.explanation: Load configuration.

M501.usage notes: User configurable settings are loaded from storage.  The settings that are loaded are firmware dependent.  For Marlin, this loads from the eeprom, while Smoothie loads from files.

examples.explanation: Reset configuration.

M502.usage notes: User configurable settings are reset.  The settings that are loaded are firmware dependent.  For Marlin, remember that eeprom is persistent across firmware flashes and an M502 + M500 should be issued.

examples.explanation: Print configuration.

M503.usage notes: Display any user configurable settings and their values.  User configurable settings vary by firmware.

M608.description: Print or configure slave settings for stepper motors.

examples.explanation: Print configuration.
Set H as a slave to Z.
Clear any slave configuration for Z.

M608.usage notes: Configures a stepper to act as a slave to another stepper.  Slave mode enables using steppers on independent drivers to be configured to act identically, avoiding using a single stepper to drive two motors - a common scenario for Z on cartesian printers.
